SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: George Rocklington

Present Address: 1023 Temperance Street

Pioneer Address: Wapiti District, Teresa Lake

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1906

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 5

How many of these were bachelor's homes? There were several bachelors.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Not very often; too busy.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Anytime.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Without.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Anytime.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes, always.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Everyone was pleased to see a visitor & it was a usual thing, one was always expected to stay for meals whatever time you went.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Usually the family, children were not left home alone.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes building "bees" for new settlers.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. Yes.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. No.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No.

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).

We didn't have a calendar & often did not know the day or date sometimes the clock would stop so we used to get the time by the sun. It had 3 tacks in a line opposite the south door on the floor & the kitchen so when the sun was shining the tacks were set for 12 noon & we found it a great help as there were no phones or any other means of finding out the time.
In the year a natural spring was found a little off the south east corner of homestead, had the water tested it was not suitable for drinking but was very useful for cattle. In winter the ice used to form about 12 feet high. I made an application for it to be kept as a public spring which was done, and 3 acres was allowed on the side of road allowance up to now the spring is still running. Our house was on the road from Shebo to Wadena & when we saw anyone go in the morning & not back before dark we hung a lighted lantern on the chimney for a guide in the dark & often people stayed over night.

Trails were very hard to find in the dark especially if there was a prairie fire through the day.

We did not have a doctor nearer than 20 miles and no nurse. My wife was often called upon in cases of sickness.
